article.title: Microscopic simulation of xenon-based optical TPCs in the presence of molecular additives

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 displays the probability distributions for the first 41 excited states of xenon upon interaction with a 30 keV electron. What is the main difference between the primary and secondary scintillation seeding mechanisms depicted?
choices: Primary scintillation involves lower energy electrons than secondary scintillation.
Secondary scintillation predominantly populates specific low-lying excited states, while primary scintillation shows a broader distribution across all states.
Primary scintillation is more efficient at exciting higher-lying states compared to secondary scintillation.
Secondary scintillation only occurs in the presence of molecular additives.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 shows the simulated time and wavelength distributions for primary and secondary scintillation in pure xenon. What does the upper plot (time distribution) indicate about the relationship between pressure and scintillation decay time?
choices: The scintillation decay time is independent of pressure.
Higher pressure leads to a faster scintillation decay time.
Lower pressure leads to a faster scintillation decay time.
Pressure only affects the wavelength distribution, not the time distribution.

Formula (5) describes the average energy required to create a VUV photon (Wsc,VUV) in pure xenon.  According to this formula, how is Wsc,VUV related to the number of excited states (Nex) directly promoted by the impinging particle?
